ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We met in a 50-minute virtual seminar on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays. Outside of class, these seminars were supplemented with PowerPoints, prerecorded "MiniLectures," and videos of sign production to aid us with learning new vocabulary and grammar. This was a "reverse classroom" model of sorts, allowing us to learn vocabulary and grammar outside of class to then use it in class later.
Live zoom classes
N/A

This class utilized a "flipped classroom" model, so vocabulary and content was learned asynchronously through videos and reading. In class, we would practice the vocabulary learned out of class through conversational prompts and games.
Virtual seminar
Recorded lecture modules on Tuesdays and Thursdays as well as live practice sessions on MWF.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not only did I learn well over one hundred signs, but I learn a lot about the Deaf community and Deaf culture--which I hate to admit I didn't know much, if anything, about before I took this course. I learned how to properly produce signs as well as catch when one of my group members wasn't producing a sign correctly. I learned how to hold conversations in ASL, both in class with my professor and outside of class with my group members. And, I'm starting to learn how to think more conceptually, as the language requires. Overall, I have such a new respect for the language and the people who speak it.
The fundamentals of ASL, Deaf culture
I learned the basics of ASL.
I learned the basics of ASL, and learned about the Deaf community and Deaf culture.

This course was focused on two main areas: communication using ASL/sign production and Deaf culture/community. We learned and practiced the vocabulary, sentence structure, and grammar involved in the production of American Sign Language. Additionally, we read about important components of the Deaf community and Deaf culture, from technologies to cultural norms to history.
Basic ASL signs and grammar.
I developed basic ASL skills, mostly covering vocabulary and some grammar.
I developed a working knowledge of ASL and deaf culture and started building skills for communicating in ASL.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All strengths, no weaknesses! The combination of "live" class and prerecorded lessons on Canvas made learning how to sign a much smoother process, at least for me. The material--vocabulary, grammar rules, homework, and Deaf culture readings--was all very interesting and engaging. I never felt like I was drowning or falling behind in the class, and that was absolutely due to the pacing of the work and instruction. Of course it would've been nice to sit in a classroom together in person, but that aside, this course was excellent.
I thought the course was set up really well. Everything was organized into the specific weeks which I thought was really helpful and kept me organized throughout the semester.
I loved this class. I have nothing bad to say about it.
This is a fantastic course and I wouldn't change a thing about it!

Honestly, this course had no weaknesses. Dr K is an incredibly engaging professor with a true dedication to each of her students. I always felt comfortable asking questions and was confident about class assignments. One major strength is the organization of the course, as each week of vocabulary is easily accessible, and assignments are very clearly posted. I also appreciated the "voice-off" policy Dr K used since the first day of class. Being in a silent environment, where we were utilizing ASL as much as possible, was both respectful to the Deaf community and helped us practice signing as much as possible. I could seriously go on and on about the strengths of the course, I learned so much about ASL and the Deaf community and was deeply interested in the subject matter.
I loved this course. No ideas for how to make the course better.

The small class size makes it very easy to stay engaged. I also liked how our assignments were spread throughout the week, so I was constantly practicing ASL. Sometimes, it was easy to miss what was said if I looked away from my laptop since ASL is visual.

I absolutely loved this course; it was the highlight of my semester by a long shot. The workload was manageable and very very fun! I was actually able to make friends in my class even in this virtual setting, and Professor Guynes was by far the best professor I've had so far.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think all of the practices succeeded! The biggest difference for a class like ours, had it met in person, would've been more conversational practice with each other. However, Dr. K had us in small groups that would often meet during class time to practice vocabulary and work on assignments together--with our mics off--which allowed for almost as much engagement as we would've experienced in an actual classroom. The video instruction outside of class time was a really good way to supplement learning without being able to meet in person.
I liked the group work. It gave us more time with the professor and it made it feel more personal which is hard to do on zoom.
Dr. K had a lot of experience teaching in an online format so class went smoothly almost all the time.
The virtual format of the class worked out really nicely (split screen on Zoom - one half for PowerPoint presentation, and other half with faces of classmates and Dr. K).

This course was translated very well to an online setting. The use of Canvas made all class materials very accessible and easy to reference in later weeks. Also, Dr K's use of screensharing to have Powerpoints support her signing helped out my peers and I understand directions and class activities. Of course, this is not an ideal setting (and I am sure we would all rather be in a seminar room together), but Dr K did a great job adapting to make the course virtual.
Dr. K was very accommodating and made the zoom transition effortless.
The course worked very well online and everything was super organized. I can't think of any ways to improve it.
I thought Zoom was actually a very efficient and effective way for this class to run! We were able to see all of the students and the professor at once which makes visual communication very easy.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES!!!!!! This was hands down (haha, pun intended) my favorite class of the semester, and I fully recommend it to anyone considering taking it. Dr. K is a gem--she is a wonderful professor and a kind person, and she will even bring her dogs to class from time to time. Yeah. It's as great as it sounds. I'd been wanting to take ASL for a while before coming to college, and I am so glad I got to start with a professor like Dr. K. The material is intellectually stimulating without being excessive or ridiculously challenging. Learning how to sign is a lot of fun, and you will see and feel your progress after just a week or two of taking the course. Take this class--you will not regret it.
Yes I would!! The material is interesting and the professor is amazing. The course is set up very well and keeps you organized.
Yes, 100%. ASL is a really cool language to learn and learning about Deaf culture alongside that was amazing as well.
Absolutely! Dr. K is one of the most kind and considerate professors I have ever had, and does a great job of teaching this course. You really learn a lot in such a short period of time.

Absolutely. Whether you are looking to fulfill the language requirement with the ASL track, or are interested in getting an introduction to ASL for practical use, this class is perfect. There are brief assignments due each day of the week, but they are very purposeful and interesting, never just busy work. I would recommend this course to any Yale student. In addition to learning ASL, I am SO glad I now know so much more about the Deaf community so I can be more understanding and respectful of any Deaf individuals I meet. I could not recommend this class more.
Absolutely yes.
I would recommend this class because the workload isn't too heavy but you come out of it having learned a lot. Dr. K also makes class very enjoyable and something to look forward to.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone!! Best class I've taken at Yale by far!
